Understandable, but not practical. Our lives go on irrespective, be it for better or for worse. Martin Luther-King Jnr said, â€œOur ultimate test is not where we stand in moments of comfort and convenience, but where we stand at times of challenge and controversyâ€. Adversity is an inevitable part of life. That being the case, what do people who are able to rise to meet the challenges and buffeting of everyday life do that separates them from those who donâ€™t? There are probably as many answers to that question as there are people, so to give simple answers to what are complex behavioural problems would be folly. There are however three things that people who learn from and grow through adversity do: 1. They understand and accept that adversity is part of human existence. That prevents them from feeling discriminated against by not asking the unanswerable question, â€œwhy meâ€? A more realistic question to ask would be, â€œwhy not meâ€? That stops them from becoming the victim and immersing themselves in the destructive state of self-pity. 2. They focus on what they can change or influence and are able to accept the things they canâ€™t. That process doesnâ€™t usually happen instantaneously, it may take some time to come to terms with. It is helpful to remind ourselves of the phrase, â€˜Grant me the SERENITY to accept the things I cannot change, the COURAGE to change the things I can and the WISDOM to know the difference. 3. Ask the question, â€œis this (thought, attitude or behaviour) helping me or hindering meâ€? The key to that question is self-awareness. When you catch yourself not thinking or behaving in your best interests or self-sabotaging, that simple question acts as an effective â€˜circuit breakerâ€™. You are then in a position to stop that thought and replace it with a more helpful one. Like it or not, experiencing adversity is part of being a human being. Nobody invites it into their lives, but if you can accept it and learn from it, it becomes one of the primary engines of human development, even if it doesnâ€™t feel like it at the time. #people #development #adversity #change
